chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: LIXA is constituted of two components: client and server. The figure below shows a typical configuration with three distinct Application Programs and four different Resource Managers.

section.title: Architectural elements
section.para: The lixad daemon process can be executed on any system: there is no need it is hosted in the same system is hosting the Application Programs. The communications between lixac are based on a TCP/IP socket.

The lixac library is embedded in the Application Programs; the communication between Application Program and lixac is based on TX (Transaction Demarcation) API, see TXspec. The library contains the logic of the LIXA Transaction Manager.

The communication between the Application Program and the Resource Managers depends on Resource Managers configuration: it may be cross memory based, TCP/IP based, etc... The communication between the lixac library and the Resource Manager depends on Resource Manager configuration and must be the same used by the Application Program.
The communication between lixac and lixad is ever istantiated by the client: the server never calls the client.

section.title: Configuring the server
section.para:
The default configuration file is etc/lixad_conf.xml and is located at the root installation path (i.e. /opt/lixa/etc/lixad_conf.xml). Below there is a sample configuration file:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <server pid_file="/tmp/lixa/var/run.pid"> <listeners> <listener domain="AF_INET" address="127.0.0.1" port="3456"/> <listener domain="AF_INET" address="0.0.0.0" port="2345"/> </listeners> <managers> <manager status_file="/tmp/lixa/var/lixad_status1"/> <manager status_file="/tmp/lixa/var/lixad_status2"/> <manager status_file="/tmp/lixa/var/lixad_status3"/> </managers> </server>
The tags and the properties of the XML file are described below:
pid_file: the file used by the server to store the daemon PID
listener: the server can activate one or more listeners; most of the times one listener is sufficient, but if you want to listen only on a subset of the address associated to the server you have to configure many
domain: the type of socket must be used to listen for clients. The only allowed type is AF_INET; this may be different in the future
address: the address must be used to listen for clients; the special value 0.0.0.0 means any address
port: the port must be used to listen for clients; it must be a free port (use command netstat to find out one)
manager: any configured manager is a server worker and has its own associated thread. The number of manager should be activated depends on the workload.
